chapters.title: The Miracle on Sycamore Lane
chapters.summary: A financially devastated family receives a life-changing offer they never applied for, moving into a luxurious mansion with a single, cryptic rule.
key_events: The Miller family—David, Sarah, teens Chloe and Liam, and young Oliver—are evicted from their apartment.
A formal letter arrives, congratulating them on winning a 'Humanitarian Tenancy' at 13 Sycamore Lane: one year, rent-free.
They visit the impossibly grand, historic mansion, met by the silent, smiling caretaker, Mr. Gable.
They sign the contract, noting only one odd clause: 'The tenancy is maintained by unanimous household consent.'
They move in, marveling at the house's perfection and how it seems to anticipate their needs.
chapters.ending_hook: That night, young Oliver sleepwalks to the grand fireplace and whispers, 'The house is happy we're here. It says we have to play the game to stay.'

chapters.title: The First Provision
chapters.summary: The family settles into their new, lavish life, but the house's supernatural nature begins to reveal itself through unsettling, personalized comforts.
key_events: The house provides: David finds his dream job offer in the study; Sarah's lost heirloom necklace appears on her dresser.
Chloe's college tuition is mysteriously paid in full; Liam gets the exact gaming rig he coveted.
Oliver draws disturbing pictures of the family with one figure crossed out each month.
They discover the house has no visible doors to the basement or the attic—just smooth walls where the entrances should be.
A family meeting dismisses Oliver's 'game' as trauma from their prior instability.
chapters.ending_hook: On the morning of their first full month, a new, ornate door appears in the hallway. A brass plaque reads: 'Eviction Suite.'

chapters.title: The Rules of the Game
chapters.summary: The true, horrific terms of their tenancy are made terrifyingly clear after the first month concludes.
key_events: The family explores the Eviction Suite: a stark, soundproofed room with a single chair and a old-fashioned intercom.
Mr. Gable delivers a formal 'Month One Compliance' letter, clarifying the clause: 'One tenant must be willingly evicted by unanimous consent.'
The house's amenities shut down—lights, heat, water—applying pressure.
Panicked arguments erupt. Is it a metaphor? A legal trick?
At the stroke of midnight, the house itself seems to groan in disappointment. The letter bursts into flame, and a new message forms in the ashes: 'Compliance Failed. Penalty Incurred.'
chapters.ending_hook: Sarah wakes to find her left hand is now cold, grey, and utterly lifeless—a permanent, visible mark of the house's displeasure.

chapters.title: The Unanimous Decision
chapters.summary: Faced with a tangible supernatural penalty, the family is forced to make their first horrific choice in the second month.
key_events: Sarah's petrified hand cannot be warmed or moved, a constant reminder of the house's power.
The family researches the mansion's history, finding vague references to 'the Selection' and previous tenants who left suddenly.
Tensions fracture the family into alliances: parents vs. kids, practicality vs. morality.
Under duress, they agree their evictee must be 'temporary'—they choose the family dog, Baxter.
With heavy hearts, they lead Baxter into the Eviction Suite. The door seals, and he vanishes silently.
chapters.ending_hook: The house's comforts return instantly. On the mantel, a new framed photo appears: a picture of Baxter, now part of a gallery of previous 'tenants.' The family realizes the evictions are permanent.

chapters.title: The Gift and the Debt
chapters.summary: After the eviction, the house rewards them lavishly, but the cost of their decision begins to poison their relationships.
key_events: The house becomes more responsive, almost affectionate, granting extravagant gifts: a car for David, designer items for Chloe.
Guilt and paranoia take root. Liam blames his parents; Oliver stops speaking and just stares at the gallery of photos.
Sarah discovers her petrified hand can now touch something invisible in the house—a cold, pulsing presence in the walls.
They find a hidden ledger listing past tenants and their monthly 'offerings,' all ending after twelve entries.
Chloe, seeking escape, finds the property boundary is now an invisible, unbreakable barrier.
chapters.ending_hook: Oliver finally speaks, pointing to the photo gallery: 'Baxter says it's lonely. It wants the next one to come play.'

chapters.title: The Candidate
chapters.summary: As the third month deadline looms, targeted psychological warfare from the house turns the family against their most vulnerable member.
key_events: The house begins to subtly isolate Liam, making him appear the problem: his music blares uncontrollably, his room is always freezing.
Whispers are heard echoing his voice, saying cruel things about other family members.
Food he likes spoils instantly; his belongings go missing and reappear in disturbing places.
A family argument, fueled by the house's manipulations, escalates to a physical shove.
A new 'suggestion' appears on the refrigerator in magnetic letters: 'LIAM DISRUPTS THE UNANIMITY.'
chapters.ending_hook: Liam, in a rage, punches the wall. His fist sinks into the now-soft plaster, which hardens instantly, trapping him. The wall begins to pull him in.

chapters.title: The Extraction
chapters.summary: The family must decide whether to ratify the house's choice of Liam or defy it and face another collective penalty.
key_events: They manage to pull Liam free from the hungry wall, which leaves his arm covered in spectral bite marks.
Liam reveals the house has been whispering to him, too, promising him freedom if he 'offers' his younger brother.
The deadline approaches. Sarah argues they must not play the game. David argues they have no choice.
In the Eviction Suite, they cannot bring themselves to say Liam's name. The intercom crackles: 'Consensus is required.'
At the last moment, Liam, broken and terrified of the house, volunteers. 'Do it. Before it chooses Oliver.'
chapters.ending_hook: Liam is evicted. The next morning, Chloe finds her brother's face in the photo gallery, but his expression is one of screaming agony, not the peaceful smiles of the others.

chapters.title: The Divided House
chapters.summary: The family is shattered into factions. Sarah and Oliver seek a way to break the contract, while David and Chloe rationalize playing by the rules to survive.
key_events: Sarah, using her petrified hand, starts to feel a 'circuitry' of pain within the house, a potential weak point.
David and Chloe become apologists, believing the house's gifts are worth the terrible cost. They begin dressing in provided period clothing.
Oliver draws a blueprint of the house's true shape, showing a monstrous, pulsing heart in the foundation.
Sarah discovers Mr. Gable is not a man, but a hollow shell of dried skin and dust—a previous tenant.
The two sides stop eating together. The house rearranges rooms, physically separating them.
chapters.ending_hook: Sarah finds a hidden message scratched under a floorboard by a past tenant: 'The only way out is to offer it what it really wants: the first one who came in.'

chapters.title: The Original Tenant
chapters.summary: Delving into the house's origins, Sarah uncovers the dark ritual that created it, revealing a potential escape clause.
key_events: Sarah's research leads her to the mansion's builder, a reclusive 19th-century industrialist named Alistair Sycamore.
He sought to create a perfect, eternal home by binding his family's souls to the foundation after a tragic fire.
The 'lottery' is a ritual to feed the house fresh souls to sustain Sycamore's own spectral existence.
The 'unanimous consent' clause is the key—the ritual requires willing participation, a choice made without coercion.
Sarah realizes the house is now coercing them, which might void the contract. They must refuse the next eviction as one.
chapters.ending_hook: She presents her findings, but David and Chloe, now deeply under the house's influence, refuse to listen. David coldly states, 'Month Four is coming. We've decided it's Oliver.'

chapters.title: The Rebellion
chapters.summary: Sarah and Oliver go to war against the house and their own family to prevent the next eviction.
key_events: Sarah and Oliver barricade themselves in a bedroom, using knowledge from the weak points to temporarily ward off the house's influence.
The house turns violent: furniture attacks, corridors become labyrinths, portraits weep blood.
David and Chloe, now fully assimilated, calmly try to negotiate through the door, their voices eerily similar.
Using her petrified hand as a key, Sarah opens a hidden passage in the wall, leading down towards the foundational 'heart.'
They descend into a dark, organic-looking basement, the source of the house's power.
chapters.ending_hook: In the pulsating core room, they find Alistair Sycamore's preserved body fused with the roots of the house—and Liam, trapped and conscious, embedded in the wall beside him.

chapters.title: The Heart of Sycamore
chapters.summary: Confronting the entity at the center of the house, Sarah must make a desperate bargain to save her remaining children.
key_events: Sycamore's spirit awakens, explaining the house is a 'family preservation engine.' True unity is sacrificing for one another.
He reveals the evictees are not consumed, but preserved within the house's memory—a fate worse than death.
To break the contract, a true, unanimous sacrifice of the *entire tenancy* must be offered: they must all willingly leave together, forfeiting the house's gifts.
David and Chloe arrive, still under the house's thrall. Sycamore offers them a choice: become his eternal heirs, or be human.
Faced with Oliver's terror and Liam's trapped suffering, David and Chloe's humanity cracks through.
chapters.ending_hook: The reunited family joins hands. Sarah speaks for them: 'We unanimously consent... to leave.' The house lets out a shriek of rage as the foundation shakes.

chapters.title: The Vacancy
chapters.summary: The family makes their final stand to break the house's hold and escape, but freedom demands a permanent price.
key_events: The house fights their decision, transforming into a monstrous, fleshy prison. The exit doors vanish.
Sycamore taunts them: leaving requires walking into the foundational fire that created him—a test of true willingness.
They must walk, as a family, into a spectral inferno that appears in the hearth, trusting it is an illusion of escape.
Holding onto each other, they step into the flames. It burns not with heat, but with the memory of every selfish choice they made.
They stumble out onto the cold, overgrown lawn of 13 Sycamore Lane. The mansion stands dark and silent behind them.
chapters.ending_hook: As they flee, a final glance back shows a 'For Let' sign materializing on the gate. Mr. Gable stands in the doorway, waving, a new stack of lottery letters in his hand. In Sarah's pocket, her petrified hand remains—a permanent, aching reminder of the tenancy.
